abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Business Environment
            Strengthening Technical Assistance Project for Malawi were
            as follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was moderate; Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory and borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes:
            projects can have valuable outcomes even when their
            objectives are not transformational. Currently, in the
            absence of the Bank's support, these processes are
            often not improved, delaying other aspects in the
            development process. Applying a theory of change is
            important for understanding which assumptions are needed to
            achieve the project objectives. Partnerships are good but do
            not underestimate time and costs of coordinating with other
            donors. It is important to incorporate the new information
            in a timely manner. Once information affecting project
            design is available, it is important not to delay the
            restructuring process. Need for effective mechanisms of
            controlling coordination costs. More complex programs such
            as matching grants may require a pilot phase and commitment
            to learning from all levels of the project.
